descripGrp.descrip: To terminate a session with a computer accessed through a communications line usually a computer that is both distant and open to many users.
In communications, the portion of a Data Terminal Equipment (DTE) device that sends data.
A transmission medium designed for high-speed data transfers over long distances. Cable modem services and Digital Subscriber Line (DSL) are examples of broadband networks.
A transmission medium designed for high-speed data transfers over long distances. Cable modem services and Digital Subscriber Line (DSL) are examples of broadband networks.
A mark placed over, under, or through a character, usually to indicate a change in phonetic value from the unmarked state.
A mark placed over, under, or through a character, usually to indicate a change in phonetic value from the unmarked state.
A feature that allows you to open any XAML file on your hard disk (or a hyperlink on a web page) and run it within a browser without compilation.
A menu that drops from the menu bar when requested and remains open without further action until the user closes it or chooses a menu item.

The movement of information from one location to another, either within a computer (as from a disk drive to memory), between a computer and an external device (as between a file server and a computer on a network), or between separate computers.

The movement of information from one location to another, either within a computer (as from a disk drive to memory), between a computer and an external device (as between a file server and a computer on a network), or between separate computers.

A server located on a network between client software, such as a Web browser, and another server. It intercepts all requests to the server to determine whether it can fulfill them itself. If not, it forwards the request to another server.
A note that helps users learn about the capabilities of a product and that helps them apply techniques and procedures specific their needs by suggesting alternative methods that are not obvious.
A method of protecting the rights of an originator of a creative work, such as a text, a piece of music, a painting, or a computer program, through law.
A webpage that serves as the starting point of a website.
Any address type that the MS Mail postoffice does not have a gateway or access component installed for routing.

An organizational feature of Windows that displays a panel on the side of the desktop with shortcuts to mini-applications, also known as gadgets. The examples of such gadgets are local weather, a photo slideshow, a dictionary, news headlines, and a Windows Media Player control.

A service or feature of Windows that enables licensing at the feature level; thereby broadening the distribution and licensing options for retailers, ISVs, and OEMs. New business models may include: trials, subscriptions, gifting, transfers, or pay-for-use.

A service or feature of Windows that enables licensing at the feature level; thereby broadening the distribution and licensing options for retailers, ISVs, and OEMs. New business models may include: trials, subscriptions, gifting, transfers, or pay-for-use.
An association established between common fields (columns) in two tables. A relationship can be one-to-one, many-to-many, or one-to-many.
The inability of a computer system or related device to operate reliably or to operate at all.
A keyboard key (often labeled "PgDn") that is often used to move the cursor down to the top of the next page or a specific number of lines. Its function may vary in different programs.
A filter that helps to identify fraudulent Web sites and protect against personal data theft.
A member of the Administrators group on the local server computer.
A chart that uses vertical bars to show data changes over a period of time or illustrate comparisons among items.
The user preferences for the formatting of dates, currencies, numbers, and so on. The user locale is a per-user setting, and does not require the user to restart or to log on or log off the computer.
A part of the user interface dedicated to a particular purpose, such as "instant message area."
The data access interface that communicates with OLE DB-compliant data sources to connect to, retrieve, manipulate, and update data.
The data access interface that communicates with OLE DB-compliant data sources to connect to, retrieve, manipulate, and update data.
A keyboard key that alternates between turning a particular operation, function, or mode on or off.
An orientation where the long dimension of a rectangular area (for example, screen, photo, or paper) is vertical.​
An orientation where the long dimension of a rectangular area (for example, screen, photo, or paper) is vertical.​
Any combination of keys that must be pressed simultaneously.
Any combination of keys that must be pressed simultaneously.
A digital document used for authentication and network security that binds a public key to an entity that holds the corresponding private key.
A digital document used for authentication and network security that binds a public key to an entity that holds the corresponding private key.
A graphical bar (think bar charts) displayed in each cell. The length of the bar is related to the cell’s value.
To gain entry to memory in order to read or write data.
A module that can contain the definition for a new object where each instance of a class creates a new object and procedures defined in the module become properties and methods of the object.
A signal sent by a device to get the attention of the processor when the device is ready to accept or send information.
A signal sent by a device to get the attention of the processor when the device is ready to accept or send information.
A signal sent by a device to get the attention of the processor when the device is ready to accept or send information.
An object created using drawing tools or commands.
Any temporary storage space used within or in conjunction with a computer, such as RAM or a USB flash drive.
A unit of computer or device memory equal to 1,024 megabytes (1,024 1,048,576, [230] bytes).
A unit of computer or device memory equal to 1,024 megabytes (1,024 1,048,576, [230] bytes).
A list of names and email addresses that are grouped under a single name.

The process of granting a person, computer process, or device access to certain information, services or functionality. Authorization is derived from the identity of the person, computer process, or device requesting access, which is verified through authentication.
A standard Windows control that supports scrolling.
To organize information, such as a list of files, in a particular order. For example, a list of files can be sorted alphabetically by name in ascending or descending order.
A reference to data stored in a document from another program.
An XML vocabulary that is used to transform XML data to another form, such as HTML, by means of a style sheet that defines presentation rules.
An XML vocabulary that is used to transform XML data to another form, such as HTML, by means of a style sheet that defines presentation rules.
To press and release a mouse button twice in rapid succession without moving the mouse. Double-clicking is a means of rapidly selecting and activating a program or program feature.
The operational state of a computer or a program.
Any disk drive, folder, or other place in which you can store files and folders. Programs will commonly ask you to choose a location to save a file.
Software that enables hardware (e.g. peripherals) to work with your computer or mobile device.
Software that enables hardware (e.g. peripherals) to work with your computer or mobile device.
A set of technologies that allows software components to interact with one another in a networked environment, regardless of the language in which the components were created.
The + character, used to indicate addition or a positive number.
The + character, used to indicate addition or a positive number.
A connection between an OLE object and its OLE server, or between a dynamic data exchange (DDE) source document and a destination document.
A connection between an OLE object and its OLE server, or between a dynamic data exchange (DDE) source document and a destination document.
To set up hardware and software.
A location on a SharePoint site where a collection of files and their associated metadata are stored.
Not in the immediate vicinity, as a computer or other device located in another place (room, building, or city) and accessible through some type of cable or communications link.

A hardware- or software-based interface used to transfer information between a computer and other devices. Hardware ports are physical connections that are visible on the outside of the computer. Software ports are the numbered gateways in programs that software programs use to exchange information.
Referring to anything that is ready for immediate use by a user or application.

A feature of Windows Vista that gives the user quick access to useful information on their computer, such as calendar appointments and the latest email message even when the computer is in standby mode or hibernating, media playback control when the computer is off, and other application notifications.
A cryptographic algorithm specified by the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) to protect sensitive information.
A cryptographic algorithm specified by the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) to protect sensitive information.
Software for capturing, editing, and arranging audio and video source material to create movies.

Microsoft Web server software, utilizing the Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) to deliver World Wide Web documents. Supports the Common Gateway Interface (CGI), the File Transfer Protocol (FTP), and Gopher.

Microsoft Web server software, utilizing the Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) to deliver World Wide Web documents. Supports the Common Gateway Interface (CGI), the File Transfer Protocol (FTP), and Gopher.
Each of a set of references that together describe the exact position of something with respect to a set of axes (or a row and column).
The timing and sequence of tasks within a project.
A file that lists errors that were encountered during an operation.

An input device used to control an on-screen cursor for such actions as "pressing" on-screen buttons in dialog boxes, choosing menu items, and selecting ranges of cells in spreadsheets or groups of words in a document.
The ÷ character.
Without difficulty.
An object that is inserted into a document from a source file and that is updated when the original source file is updated.

A tested, cumulative set of all hotfixes, security updates, critical updates and updates, as well as additional fixes for problems found internally since the release of the product. Service packs may also contain a limited number of customer requested design changes or features, and contain all fixes since the previous service pack or RTM.

A tested, cumulative set of all hotfixes, security updates, critical updates and updates, as well as additional fixes for problems found internally since the release of the product. Service packs may also contain a limited number of customer requested design changes or features, and contain all fixes since the previous service pack or RTM.
The "one" side of two related tables in a one-to-many relationship. A primary table should have a primary key and each record should be unique.
The ´ character.

In reference to a single microcomputer, the sum of a system's internal and external components, including memory, disk drives, keyboard, video, and generally less critical add-on hardware, such as a mouse, modem, or printer. Software (the operating system and various device drivers), the user's choices established through configuration files such as the AUTOEXEC.BAT and CONFIG.SYS files on IBM PCs and compatibles, and sometimes hardware (switches and jumpers) are needed to "configure the configuration" to work correctly. Although system configuration can be changed, as by adding more memory or disk capacity, the basic structure of the system--its architecture--remains the same.
To reconcile the differences between two sets of stored data, where once the differences are determined, both sets are updated to be the same.
To reconcile the differences between two sets of stored data, where once the differences are determined, both sets are updated to be the same.
The location where the user is currently directing input.

A folder that provides you with a convenient place to store documents, graphics, or other files you want to access quickly. When you save a file in a program such as WordPad or Paint, the file is automatically saved in My Documents, unless you choose a different folder.
A program designed to amuse or scare a user, for example by imitating the actions of a virus, without actually harming the computer.
The set of coordinates that a cell occupies on a worksheet. For example, the reference of the cell that appears at the intersection of column B and row 3 is B3.
A tutorial outlining basic Windows features, workflow and information.
A fraction that is written on a single line: the numerator is placed on the left, followed by the fraction bar, and the denominator on the right. Example: 3/4

A hyphen that is used to control where a word or phrase breaks if it falls at the end of a line. For example, you can specify that the word "nonprinting" breaks as "non-printing" rather than "nonprint-ing."

A hyphen that is used to control where a word or phrase breaks if it falls at the end of a line. For example, you can specify that the word "nonprinting" breaks as "non-printing" rather than "nonprint-ing."

A hyphen that is used to control where a word or phrase breaks if it falls at the end of a line. For example, you can specify that the word "nonprinting" breaks as "non-printing" rather than "nonprint-ing."

To transfer information either to a storage device, such as a disk, or to an output device, such as the monitor or a printer. Writing is the means by which a computer provides the results of processing. A computer can also be said to write to the screen when it displays information on the monitor.
Any self-contained piece of work created with an application program and, if saved on disk, given a unique filename by which it can be retrieved.

A type of object within a process that runs program instructions. Using multiple threads allows concurrent operations within a process and enables one process to run different parts of its program on different processors simultaneously. A thread has its own set of registers, its own kernel stack, a thread environment block, and a user stack in the address space of its process.
Not visible to the user.
Hardware that transfers audio and video from an external source, such as a VCR or camcorder, to a computer.

descripGrp.descrip: A number that gives a general indication of the performance capability of your computer's hardware.

On the IBM PC/XT and AT and compatible keyboards, a key on the top row of the numeric keypad that controls the effect of the cursor control keys and sometimes prevents the screen from scrolling. On the enhanced and Macintosh keyboards, this key is to the right of the function keys on the top row. Many modern applications ignore the Scroll Lock setting.
A part of an IrDA infrared communication protocol used so that devices can learn about the services offered by another device.
A part of an IrDA infrared communication protocol used so that devices can learn about the services offered by another device.
A graphic design applied to a collection of numbers, symbols, and characters and that describes a certain typeface, along with other qualities such as size, spacing, and pitch.
In the United States, the postal code assigned to all addresses.

An operating system feature that allows executable routines (generally serving a specific function or set of functions) to be stored separately as files with .dll extensions. These routines are loaded only when needed by the program that calls them.

An operating system feature that allows executable routines (generally serving a specific function or set of functions) to be stored separately as files with .dll extensions. These routines are loaded only when needed by the program that calls them.
The block of filled-in cells that includes the currently selected cell or cells. The region extends in all directions to the first empty row or column.
A circular or pamphlet for distribution, normally used for advertisements.
An address of a cell in a worksheet that does not change when the address is copied to a new cell.
Digital media that is delivered in a continuous flow across a network.
An entity, such as a device or program, that connects to another entity over a network.
An entity, such as a device or program, that connects to another entity over a network.
To remove unused space from data tables.
The item on the File menu that writes data (typically a file) to a storage medium.
Text or symbols indicating that a computer program is waiting for input from the user.
An expression which results in a true or false value when calculated.
An expression which results in a true or false value when calculated.
A font effect in which lowercase text appears as capital letters in a reduced font size.
An on-screen scale marked off in inches or other units of measure and used to show line widths, tab settings, paragraph indents, and so on.
To gain access to a specific computer, program, or network by identifying oneself with a username and a password.
A collection of comments that users attach to web pages and documents.

The work area on a computer screen that simulates the top of an actual desk. The desktop contains the Recycle Bin and other icons (shortcuts to programs, files, folders, and various types of documents such as letters, reports, or pictures) that you can arrange on the electronic desktop just as you would arrange real objects on top of a desk.

The process of starting or resetting a computer or a device. When first turned on (cold boot) or reset (warm boot), the computer runs the software that loads and starts the computer's operating system, which prepares it for use.

The process of starting or resetting a computer or a device. When first turned on (cold boot) or reset (warm boot), the computer runs the software that loads and starts the computer's operating system, which prepares it for use.
A fraction that is written on a downward angle: the diagonal fraction bar is placed down and to the right of the numerator, and the denominator is slightly down and to the right of the fraction bar.

Management of a computer and its processing abilities so as to maintain order as tasks and activities are carried out. Control applies to measures designed to ensure error-free actions carried out at the right time and in the right order relative to other data-handling or hardware-based activities.
A collection of buttons representing hyperlinks to pages both within a Web site and to external sites.
Of or pertaining to a device or service that appears to the user as something it actually is not or that does not physically exist.
An application that enables remote users to connect to a network.
An application that enables remote users to connect to a network.

Having two components, alternatives, or outcomes. The binary number system has 2 as its base, so values are expressed as combinations of two digits, 0 and 1. These two digits can represent the logical values true and false as well as numerals, and they can be represented in an electronic device by the two states on and off, recognized as two voltage levels. Therefore, the binary number system is at the heart of digital computing.
How a program's action is determined if the user does not make a choice or supply a required value.
A note or annotation that an author or reviewer adds to a document.

A System Audio Effects (SYSFX) component used to provide a more immersive audio experience in the Windows Media Player and thus an improved listening experience by utilizing the available speakers that a user has attached to his/her PC by sending audio to all of the speakers, regardless of the number of channels the content contains. This will provide a better sounding experience for stereo and quadraphonic content being rendered on multi-channel playback systems.
A binary number that uniquely identifies a host (computer) connected to the Internet to other Internet hosts, for the purposes of communication through the transfer of packets.
A collection of email addresses that is treated as a single recipient for email distribution purposes, and that is created by and available to an individual Outlook user.
The program that enables users to send and receive business card information digitally and shares data storage with Outlook.
A process for removing redundant data from a digital media file or stream to reduce its size or the bandwidth used.
A distinctive symbol that identifies a person, business, or organization.
A bar chart subtype that shows the relationship of individual items to the whole.
A processor that performs additional functions or assists the CPU.
To translate all the source code of a program from a high-level language into object code prior to execution of the program.
To translate all the source code of a program from a high-level language into object code prior to execution of the program.
The first row in a spreadsheet. The header row contains category labels that describe the contents of the columns.
To display the subentries contained within a folder or outline view.
A command that will use a print driver installed by OneNote to create an image of a wide variety of filetypes. Files are printed to the print driver and inserted as images into OneNote.

The key arrangement used for a particular keyboard, including such factors as the number of keys (101 is the current standard) and the configuration of the keys (QWERTY is the United States standard). Some proprietary systems use different layouts, and many allow you to map the keys to characters according to your preferences.
In a PC-compatible computer, the disk drive that the BIOS uses to automatically load the operating system when the computer is turned on.

A specification for connecting users on an Ethernet network to the Internet through a broadband connection, such as a single DSL line, wireless device, or cable modem. Using PPPoE and a broadband modem, LAN users can gain individual authenticated access to high-speed data networks. By combining Ethernet and Point-to-Point Protocol (PPP), PPPoE provides an efficient way to create a separate connection for each user to a remote server.

A specification for connecting users on an Ethernet network to the Internet through a broadband connection, such as a single DSL line, wireless device, or cable modem. Using PPPoE and a broadband modem, LAN users can gain individual authenticated access to high-speed data networks. By combining Ethernet and Point-to-Point Protocol (PPP), PPPoE provides an efficient way to create a separate connection for each user to a remote server.
The individual, or account, to whom an email message is sent.
One of four fields of an SCODE. It is a unique number that is assigned to represent the error or warning.
A software system that enables applications to interact with hardware and that manages software resources on a computer.
To press and release a mouse button once without moving the mouse, usually to select or deselect an item or to activate a program or program feature.

The degree to which a computer, an attached device, a data file, or a program can work with or understand the same commands, formats, or language as another. True compatibility means that any operational differences are invisible to people and programs alike.

Existing in reference to two measures, such as height and width--for example, a two-dimensional model drawn with reference to an x-axis and a y-axis, or a two-dimensional array of numbers placed in rows and columns.

Existing in reference to two measures, such as height and width--for example, a two-dimensional model drawn with reference to an x-axis and a y-axis, or a two-dimensional array of numbers placed in rows and columns.
Pertaining to something for which an answer is not available or appropriate.
Pertaining to something for which an answer is not available or appropriate.
Pertaining to something for which an answer is not available or appropriate.
Text displayed by Web browsers during image downloads for users who have graphics turned off, and for users who rely on screen-reading software to convert graphics on the screen to spoken words.
Text displayed by Web browsers during image downloads for users who have graphics turned off, and for users who rely on screen-reading software to convert graphics on the screen to spoken words.
Anything owned or controlled by a business, tangible or intangible, that has monetary value and was acquired at a measurable cost.
A static report that contains data captured at a specific point in time.
A static report that contains data captured at a specific point in time.

A statement issued by an online service that indicates what activities users may or may not engage in while logged into the service. For example, some providers prohibit users from engaging in commercial activity on the network.

A statement issued by an online service that indicates what activities users may or may not engage in while logged into the service. For example, some providers prohibit users from engaging in commercial activity on the network.
A monitor designed to work with a video card or adapter to produce text or graphics images in color.
The point size of a set of characters in a particular typeface.
The menu option that displays the folders available in a user's mailbox.
A toggle key that, when on, shifts the alphabetic characters on the keyboard to uppercase.
A toggle key that, when on, shifts the alphabetic characters on the keyboard to uppercase.
A user’s private information such as temporary files, history, passwords, web form entries, and cookies that captures Internet surfing and other online activities.
A set of strategies for adjusting the recognizer to an individual’s user’s handwriting, e.g. the shapes of their characters or the specific words they use and don’t use.

A set of routines that an application uses to request and carry out lower-level services performed by a computer's or device's operating system. These routines usually carry out maintenance tasks such as managing files and displaying information.
A data type used in some programming languages, notably C, to declare variables that can store floating-point numbers.
To reduce the size of a set of data, such as a file or a communications message, so that it can be stored in less space or transmitted with less bandwidth.
An orientation of printed paper where the printed side is away from a surface. For example, paper is face up when it is placed in a copier with the printed side away from the copying surface.

A frame that can contain check boxes, toggle buttons, and option buttons on a form, report, or data access page. You use an option group to present alternatives from which the user can select a single option.
To extend over and cover a part of something.
Information that cannot be found or recovered.
An overlapped window used for dialog boxes, message boxes, and other temporary windows that appear outside an application's primary window.
An optical disc format used to store video on standard compact discs developed by China Recording Standards Committee in competition to the DVD format.
An optical disc format used to store video on standard compact discs developed by China Recording Standards Committee in competition to the DVD format.
A grouping of dimension members or items from a data source that are named and treated as a single unit and can be referenced or reused multiple times.
An orientation of printed paper where the printed side is against a surface. For example, paper is face down when it is placed in a copier with the printed side against the copying surface.
Shading made up of regularly spaced, intersecting lines.
A graphic map that can document procedures, analyze processes, indicate work or information flow, or track cost and efficiency.
A pictorial graphic such as a digital photograph or illustration.
A pictorial graphic such as a digital photograph or illustration.
A pictorial graphic such as a digital photograph or illustration.

An advanced file system designed for use specifically with the Windows NT operating system. It supports long filenames, full security access control, file system recovery, extremely large storage media, and various features for the Windows NT POSIX subsystem. It also supports object-oriented applications by treating all files as objects with user-defined and system-defined attributes.

An advanced file system designed for use specifically with the Windows NT operating system. It supports long filenames, full security access control, file system recovery, extremely large storage media, and various features for the Windows NT POSIX subsystem. It also supports object-oriented applications by treating all files as objects with user-defined and system-defined attributes.
A folder that stores messages that have been created but not yet sent.
Pertaining to text that is aligned along the right margin.
A nonprinting mark you insert to show the end of a section.
The unique, 25-character code on a prepaid card that adds computer use time to your prepaid computer or that pays for your subscription.

The standard used to measure screen and printer resolution, expressed as the number of dots that a device can display or print per linear inch. The greater the number of dots per inch, the better the resolution.

The standard used to measure screen and printer resolution, expressed as the number of dots that a device can display or print per linear inch. The greater the number of dots per inch, the better the resolution.

A form of trojan that causes systems equipped with modems to dial phone numbers without the consent of the user. In most cases, the phone numbers dialed are premium rate numbers which result in unexpected charges on the affected user's phone bill.

A view that summarizes and analyzes data in a datasheet or form. You can use different levels of detail or organize data by dragging the fields and items, or by showing and hiding items in the drop-down lists for the fields.
A report contained within another report.
A group of related web pages that is hosted by an HTTP server on the World Wide Web or an intranet.
A group of related web pages that is hosted by an HTTP server on the World Wide Web or an intranet.

A device that enables the transmission of typed messages over phone lines. These devices typically include keyboards for typing messages to send and display and/or printers to receive messages from one device to another.

descripGrp.descrip: A device that enables the transmission of typed messages over phone lines. These devices typically include keyboards for typing messages to send and display and/or printers to receive messages from one device to another.

A device that enables the transmission of typed messages over phone lines. These devices typically include keyboards for typing messages to send and display and/or printers to receive messages from one device to another.
Properties, such as title, subject, and author, that are stored with each data access page.
Pertaining to a type of layout consisting of a collection of “Row-Wise Groupings”. A stacked layout most resembles a form with name/value pairs (label, textbox).

The suite of networking protocols arranged in four layers, which are called the link layer, internet layer, transport layer, and application layer, and that includes IP in the internet layer and TCP in the transport layer.

The suite of networking protocols arranged in four layers, which are called the link layer, internet layer, transport layer, and application layer, and that includes IP in the internet layer and TCP in the transport layer.

An optical input device that uses light-sensing equipment to capture an image on paper or some other object. Captured image data is converted into binary files that can be stored and manipulated by computer programs.

A device that connects networks using different communications protocols so that information can be passed from one to the other. A gateway both transfers information and converts it to a form compatible with the protocols used by the receiving network.
A group of computers that are connected on a network and share resources, such as printers and files.
A group of computers that are connected on a network and share resources, such as printers and files.
The processes involved in the capture, storage, display, and printing of graphical images.
A window that mimics an old MS-DOS display for typing command-line instructions.
To emphasize displayed characters, as by displaying them in reverse video (light on dark rather than dark on light, and vice versa) or against a colored background.
A collection of data formatted to allow for easy search and retrieval.
An object in a filesystem that contains files and other directories.

The tool which enables users to automatically perform routine tasks on a chosen computer by monitoring whatever criteria the users choose to initiate the tasks (referred to as triggers) and then executing the tasks when the criteria is met.
The cross-Office feature that automatically recovers content if the user's program or computer malfunctions.
A row in the upper part of the Macro window in which you enter macro names, actions, conditions, and comments associated with a particular macro or macro group.
Pertaining to an entity such as the device, program, file, record or portion of the screen that is currently operational or subject to command operations.
A value that a function or a method receives from a caller to perform computations.
The likelihood of a computer system or device continuing to function over a given period of time and under specified conditions.
A set of individual strokes in the Unicode Standard used to compose Chinese/Japanese/Korean (CJK) ideographs.
A key on IBM PC and compatible keyboards that normally causes the computer to send a character-based “picture” of the screen contents to the printer.
A symbol that carries meaning in language, such as a letter, number, punctuation mark, or emoticon.
In I/O operations, to prevent execution of a thread.
To halt a process or action, typically without restoring the prior state.

The electronic circuit in a computer that generates a steady stream of timing pulses--the digital signals that synchronize every operation. The system clock signal is precisely set by a quartz crystal, typically at a specific frequency between 1 and 50 megahertz. The clock rate of a computer is one of the prime determinants of its overall processing speed, and it can go as high as the other components of the computer allow.

The electronic circuit in a computer that generates a steady stream of timing pulses--the digital signals that synchronize every operation. The system clock signal is precisely set by a quartz crystal, typically at a specific frequency between 1 and 50 megahertz. The clock rate of a computer is one of the prime determinants of its overall processing speed, and it can go as high as the other components of the computer allow.

A component of a scroll bar that indicates the relative position (and optionally the proportion) of the visible information relative to the entire amount of information. The user can drag the scroll box to view areas of information not currently visible.
The … character. Can also be represented by entering three dots with no spaces in between (...). Used to convey incompleteness.
The process of producing copies of documents, publications, or images in high volume.
Pertaining to Microsoft software which is published by Microsoft, properly licensed, and fully supported by Microsoft or a trusted partner.
A proposed standard digital rights management (DRM) markup language which enables users to specify rights and conditions associated with resources, such as digital content or Web services.
A proposed standard digital rights management (DRM) markup language which enables users to specify rights and conditions associated with resources, such as digital content or Web services.
A workbook that is configured to allow multiple users on a network to view and make changes at the same time. Each user who saves the workbook sees the changes that are made by other users.
A wizard that allows third-party developers to achieve the same look in their dialog boxes as Aero.
A grouping of properties presented as a tabbed page of a property sheet.
The W3C standard language used for writing XML schema documents.
A distinct chunk of text that is indicated by formatting such as indentation, numbering, or a new line.
In word processing, a string of characters displayed or printed in a single horizontal row.

The process of viewing and updating the actual progress of tasks so that you can see progress across time, evaluate slippage of tasks, compare scheduled or baseline data to actual data, and check the completion percentage of tasks and your project.
A line added to a chart that makes it easier to view and evaluate data.
A program that invokes other programs in order to accomplish its tasks.
The action of pressing and releasing one of the mouse buttons.
A computer hardware component providing access to a network.
To remove part of a document, usually placing it temporarily in memory so that the cut portion can be inserted (pasted) elsewhere.
A formula that checks whether a given value is valid for a particular field.
Descriptive text that is associated with a piece of content, such as an image.
A property of a field that defines the kinds of data the field can store.
A form of storage characterized by high capacity (roughly 650 MB) and the use of laser optics instead of magnetic means for reading data.
A form of storage characterized by high capacity (roughly 650 MB) and the use of laser optics instead of magnetic means for reading data.

A feature of an application that displays data in the form of an image, diagram, or animation. For example, some databases can interpret and show data in the form of a two- or three-dimensional model.

A feature of an application that displays data in the form of an image, diagram, or animation. For example, some databases can interpret and show data in the form of a two- or three-dimensional model.

A feature of an application that displays data in the form of an image, diagram, or animation. For example, some databases can interpret and show data in the form of a two- or three-dimensional model.
To make resources, such as folders, printers, files, photos, available to others.
A device that reacts or responds to requests or events.
A control you place on a form or report to contain an unbound object.
To execute a group of statements repeatedly.
To change a system or a data file to make it more current.

An individual value plotted in a chart and represented together with other data points by bars, columns, lines, pie or doughnut slices, dots, and various other shapes called data markers. Data markers of the same color constitute a data series.

An individual value plotted in a chart and represented together with other data points by bars, columns, lines, pie or doughnut slices, dots, and various other shapes called data markers. Data markers of the same color constitute a data series.

An individual value plotted in a chart and represented together with other data points by bars, columns, lines, pie or doughnut slices, dots, and various other shapes called data markers. Data markers of the same color constitute a data series.
The Microsoft Office Web application that provides secure access to email, personal calendar, group scheduling, and collaboration applications on Microsoft Exchange Server with only a Web browser.
A property that defines valid input values for a field or record in a table, or a control on a form.
Able to be both read from and written to.
In an Active Directory forest, a server that contains a writable copy of the Active Directory database, participates in Active Directory replication, and controls access to network resources.
In an Active Directory forest, a server that contains a writable copy of the Active Directory database, participates in Active Directory replication, and controls access to network resources.

The process of validating software with the manufacturer. Activation confirms the genuine status of a product and that the product key has not been compromised. It establishes a relationship between the software’s product key and a particular installation of that software on a device.
The | character.
The | character.

Software that enables a program to work with the user (the user interface, which can be a command-line interface, menu-driven, or a graphical user interface), with another program such as the operating system, or with the computer's hardware.
The = character.
The ability for two or more software applications to work together with little effort from the user.
A feature of Windows that checks for problems associated with network connections.
A feature of Windows that checks for problems associated with network connections.
To load the program and installation files onto your computer or device so that the program runs correctly.
A symbolic value used in place of a real value that is unknown or unavailable at the current time, or that is not displayed for security reasons.

Capable of using or being displayed on the full area of a display screen. Applications running in windowing environments, although they might use the entire area of the screen, commonly allocate different areas to different windows, any of which can be enlarged to fill the entire screen.
To make an entity nonfunctional.
To make an entity nonfunctional.
A feature that allows users to check and remove personal and other sensitive information from a document.
A round, flat piece of nonmagnetic, shiny metal encased in a plastic coating, designed to be read from and written to by optical (laser) technology.
To break input into smaller chunks so that a program can act upon the information.
A device used to store information.
To put into use.
A control designed to contain content such as placeholder or sample text or images that is updated by the user, or pre-defined lists of items from which users can select.
Pertaining to an operation or feature that involves moving objects on the screen with a mouse, a similar input device or a eventually a finger.
A control that allows users to digitally sign a form or document.
A designation used to conduct sorting or searching operations.
To enter numbers on a device, such as telephone or mobile, in order to make a phone call.
A graphic symbol used on the user interface to assist with navigation.
An area of storage that is formatted with a file system and has an identifier to access it.
A program that searches for key words in documents, databases, Internet content or other files.
A list of entities such as people, groups, or organizations with whom users communicate.
A combination of keystrokes that can be used to perform a task that would otherwise require a mouse or other pointing device.
A graphical control used to display text.
A field in the row or column area that contains custom groups as its items.
A link that specifies a full path to a resource, such that the destination of the link doesn’t change based on where it is linking from.
A visual effect that colors, tweaks, or otherwise graphically alters fonts.
In mathematics, an action performed on a set of entities that produces a new entity. Examples of mathematical operations are addition and subtraction.
A successful retrieval of a record matching a query.
An authentication process that permits a user to log on to a system once with a single set of credentials to access multiple applications or services.
An installation where only the necessary components are installed on a system.
A view on a calendar that displays items such as meetings and events from left to right on a time scale and that can incorporate items from multiple calendars.
To modify the value of a property or attribute.
A definition of the structure of a particular type of data, which includes a definition of the allowed attributes and allowed relationships with other objects.
A unit of information within a markup language that is defined by a tag, or a pair of tags surrounding some content, and includes any attributes defined within the initial tag.
A name-value pair, separated by an equal sign and included in a tagged element, that modifies features of an element. All XML attribute values are strings enclosed in quotation marks.

An encryption algorithm system included as part of the 802.11 standard, developed by the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers as a security measure to protect wireless LANs from casual eavesdropping. WEP uses a shared secret key to encrypt packets before transmission between wireless LAN devices and monitors packets in transit to detect attempts at modification. WEP offers both 40-bit and 128-bit hardware-based encryption options.

An encryption algorithm system included as part of the 802.11 standard, developed by the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers as a security measure to protect wireless LANs from casual eavesdropping. WEP uses a shared secret key to encrypt packets before transmission between wireless LAN devices and monitors packets in transit to detect attempts at modification. WEP offers both 40-bit and 128-bit hardware-based encryption options.
The symbol or character used to indicate that a word, phrase, symbol, or design is a trademark, but not a registered trademark.
An area of memory reserved for temporarily holding data before that data is used by a receiving device or application. Buffering protects against the interruption of data flow.
When referring to a device, to remove the corresponding device drivers from the hard disk and physically remove the device from the computer.
A horizontal bar at the top of a window that displays the name of the window.
A single character that represents a sequence of characters, usually a combination of a base character and one or more diacritics.
A message that notifies you of a build issue.
Of, pertaining to, or characterized by capital letters.
The act of modifying the pages of a Web site so that its content is more easily discoverable by Internet search engines.
A collection of control flow and data flow elements that runs as a unit.
A report containing news or information, can be printed or distributed electronically.
Damaged. Mostly used in regard to files or data.
An individual box or button with which users enter information on an electronic form.
A quality of a product to be directly or indirectly usable by individuals with disabilities.
Pertaining to a process, tool, etc. that is enabled by Windows Live.
A network-enabled host running Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) management software. This software requests information from SNMP agents.
A network-enabled host running Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) management software. This software requests information from SNMP agents.
A feature that enables the user to compact or collapse rows when viewing several levels of data.
A searchable collection of articles and facts about a particular subject area.
A searchable collection of articles and facts about a particular subject area.
A piece of software that functions as an electronic calendar used for scheduling.
A piece of software that functions as an electronic calendar used for scheduling.
Generally, any part of a computer system or network, such as a disk drive, printer, or memory, that can be allotted to a running program or a process.
A rectangular bar displayed in an application's window, often at the top, from which menus can be selected by the user.
A message that appears at a specified interval before an appointment, meeting, or task that announces when the activity is set to occur.
An amount that is the difference between the sum of debit entries and the sum of credit entries entered into an account during a financial period.
To change between states or modes.
The InfoPath design environment in which you can create or modify a form template.
To associate two pieces of information with one another.
Row or column labels that are printed at the top of or on the left side of every page on a printed worksheet.
The entire chart and all its elements.

The set of essential software routines that test computer hardware at startup, start the operating system, and support the transfer of information between hardware devices. The BIOS is stored in read-only memory (ROM) so that it can be run when the computer is turned on. Although critical to performance, the BIOS is usually invisible to computer users.

The set of essential software routines that test computer hardware at startup, start the operating system, and support the transfer of information between hardware devices. The BIOS is stored in read-only memory (ROM) so that it can be run when the computer is turned on. Although critical to performance, the BIOS is usually invisible to computer users.
A person responsible for planning, configuring, and managing the day-to-day operation of the network.
A notification sent from one blog to another. It is a way for bloggers to let each other know when one of them has made a reference to another's blog entry.
An attribute of an object that is used to define its state, appearance, or value.
A three-dimensional edge effect that is applied to the border of an object.
In programming, the order and sequence of input and output.
The date after which information or a resource is no longer valid.

A predefined set of harmonized colors that you can apply to text and objects. Text and objects with an applied scheme color will change automatically when you switch to a new color scheme or modify the current color scheme.
A table inserted within a table cell. If you use a table to lay out a page, and you want to use another table to arrange the information, you can insert a nested table.
A document listing common questions and answers on a particular subject.
To bring information from one system or program into another.
A meaningful shorthand that makes it easier to understand the purpose of a cell reference, constant, formula, or table, each of which may be difficult to comprehend at first glance.
A reusable magnetic storage medium. The floppy disk used today is the rigid 3.5-inch microfloppy that holds 1.44 MB. It is called floppy because the first varieties were housed in bendable jackets.
A reusable magnetic storage medium. The floppy disk used today is the rigid 3.5-inch microfloppy that holds 1.44 MB. It is called floppy because the first varieties were housed in bendable jackets.
A node with subordinate node(s), called children.
A process of selecting nonadjacent and adjacent files and objects.
A sound emitted by the receiver of a telephone that indicates that a number can be dialed.
A mode of setup that allows network administrators to silently deploy to client computers.
A portable computer that combines a processor, screen, and keyboard in a single case. The screen folds down onto the keyboard when not in use.

The quality of sameness or equivalence, in the case of computers usually referring to an error-checking procedure in which the number of 1s must always be the same --either even or odd-- for each group of bits transmitted without error.
A shaded outline that appears behind an object or text and creates the illusion of depth.
A shaded outline that appears behind an object or text and creates the illusion of depth.
A photo organizer used to view, manage, and edit digital pictures.
The — character, based on the width of an uppercase M and used primarily to set off sentence elements.

An Intel microprocessor that uses explicitly parallel instruction set computing and 64-bit memory addressing. "Itanium-based" refers to systems or platforms that are based on the Itanium processor. "Itanium2-based" refers to systems or platforms that are based on the Itanium2 processor. "Itanium architecture-based" refers to systems or platforms that are based on the Itanium and Itanium2 processors.
A group of characters that have some relationship in common.
The family of Microsoft Visual Studio add-in software that allows developers to use Visual Basic and Visual C# to develop and customize applications built on the Microsoft .NET Framework.

The family of Microsoft Visual Studio add-in software that allows developers to use Visual Basic and Visual C# to develop and customize applications built on the Microsoft .NET Framework.
The vertical bar at the right of a window that users can click to move through a document.
The vertical bar at the right of a window that users can click to move through a document.
A menu item with options that can be applied to a file before it is shared with others (e.g. 'Mark as Final' or 'Add a Digital Signature').

An application commonly used for budgets, forecasting, and other finance-related tasks that organizes data values using cells, where the relationships between cells are defined by formulas. A change to one cell produces changes to related cells. Spreadsheet programs usually provide graphing capabilities for output and a variety of formatting options for text, numeric values, and graph features.

An application commonly used for budgets, forecasting, and other finance-related tasks that organizes data values using cells, where the relationships between cells are defined by formulas. A change to one cell produces changes to related cells. Spreadsheet programs usually provide graphing capabilities for output and a variety of formatting options for text, numeric values, and graph features.
A file that contains configuration information for a specific user, such as desktop settings, persistent network connections, and application settings.
A copy of a database that is a member of a replica set and can be synchronized with other replicas in the set.
A performer of a song or other audio recording.
The process of adding software to a computer system.
A tool or feature that allows users to see different fonts, typography formats, and lettershapes that display on the computer and/or on Web sites.
The number of bits transmitted every second, used as a measure of the speed at which a device, such as a modem, can transfer data.
The number of bits transmitted every second, used as a measure of the speed at which a device, such as a modem, can transfer data.
A keyboard key that moves the cursor to the left, one character at a time, usually erasing each character as it moves.
Of, pertaining to, or being an object or image having or appearing to have all three spatial dimensions (length, width, and depth).
Of, pertaining to, or being an object or image having or appearing to have all three spatial dimensions (length, width, and depth).
The vertical reference line on a grid, chart, or graph that has horizontal and vertical dimensions.
The complementary tasks of gathering and distributing data. Input is data that is acquired from a device or entered by the user through a device. Output is data that is sent to a device.
The complementary tasks of gathering and distributing data. Input is data that is acquired from a device or entered by the user through a device. Output is data that is sent to a device.

The creation of an image containing geometric models, using color and shading to give the image a realistic look. Usually part of a geometric modeling package such as a CAD program, rendering uses mathematics to describe the location of a light source in relation to the object and to calculate the way in which the light would create highlights, shading, and variations in color. The degree of realism can range from opaque, shaded polygons to images approximating photographs in their complexity.
A feature that provides detailed Web site statistics and reports related to the subscriber's Web site.
The Microsoft owned technology that allows the embedding and linking of objects, such as documents, allowing for the addition of different kinds of data from different applications.
The Microsoft owned technology that allows the embedding and linking of objects, such as documents, allowing for the addition of different kinds of data from different applications.
A small device used to store information. USB flash drives plug into computer USB ports so you can copy information to or from them, making it easy to share and transport information.
A set of possible values for an independent variable in a function or for a database attribute.
A chunk of data that a Web server sends to a browser, which in turn saves it and sends it back when accessing the Web server again.

The ability of a word-processing program or a text-editing program to break lines of text automatically to stay within the page margins or window boundaries of a document without the user having to do so with carriage returns, as is typically necessary on a typewriter.

The ability of a word-processing program or a text-editing program to break lines of text automatically to stay within the page margins or window boundaries of a document without the user having to do so with carriage returns, as is typically necessary on a typewriter.

The ability of a word-processing program or a text-editing program to break lines of text automatically to stay within the page margins or window boundaries of a document without the user having to do so with carriage returns, as is typically necessary on a typewriter.

The ability of a word-processing program or a text-editing program to break lines of text automatically to stay within the page margins or window boundaries of a document without the user having to do so with carriage returns, as is typically necessary on a typewriter.
Software that monitors activity, such as keystrokes or screen images. These programs are often installed by the computer owner or administrator, and are only a threat if they are unexpected.

A directory of information about data sets, files, or a database. It usually describes where a data set, file or database entity is located and may also include other information, such as the type of device on which each data set or file is stored.
An organization that provides a connection to the internet and services related to that.
An organization that provides a connection to the internet and services related to that.
An organization that provides a connection to the internet and services related to that.
An organization that provides a connection to the internet and services related to that.

Self-propagating malicious software that can automatically distribute itself from one computer to another through network connections. A worm can take harmful action, such as consuming network or local system resources, possibly causing a denial of service attack.
A security label that accompanies all Microsoft products distributed by original equipment manufacturers (OEMs).
A security label that accompanies all Microsoft products distributed by original equipment manufacturers (OEMs).
A security solution that segregates one portion of a network from another portion, allowing only authorized network traffic to pass through according to traffic filtering rules.

In Windows Presentation Foundation, an event routing strategy where the event instance moves down the element tree (starting at the root of the visual tree and ending with the source). The names of events that use this routing strategy are prefixed with the word "Preview". These events have the same signature as their counterparts that use the bubbling event routing strategy.
A listing of keywords and associated data that point to the location of more comprehensive information, such as files and records on a disk or record keys in a database.

A set of instructions in some computer language intended to be executed on a computer so as to perform some task. The term usually implies a self-contained entity, as opposed to a routine or a library.
A trojan that captures and/or transmits passwords to an attacker.

The special identification code printed as a set of vertical bars of differing widths on books, grocery products, and other merchandise. Used for rapid, error-free input in such facilities as libraries, hospitals, and grocery stores, bar codes represent binary information that can be read by an optical scanner. The coding can include numbers, letters, or a combination of the two; some codes include built-in error checking and can be read in either direction.
A software technique for smoothing the jagged appearance of curved or diagonal lines caused by poor resolution on a display screen by adjusting the brightness or color of surrounding pixels.
A software technique for smoothing the jagged appearance of curved or diagonal lines caused by poor resolution on a display screen by adjusting the brightness or color of surrounding pixels.
A software technique for smoothing the jagged appearance of curved or diagonal lines caused by poor resolution on a display screen by adjusting the brightness or color of surrounding pixels.
An interactive controls often found in graphical user interfaces used to enable or disable one or more features or options from a set.

An input device with the following features: a flat-bottomed casing designed to be gripped by one hand; one or more buttons on the top; a multidirectional detection device (a ball, laser or optical device) on the bottom; and a cable or wireless connection to the computer.
A utility or feature that aids in accomplishing a task or set of tasks.
A type of CD-ROM that can be written (only once) on a CD recorder and read on a CD-ROM drive.
A type of CD-ROM that can be written (only once) on a CD recorder and read on a CD-ROM drive.
The ability of hardware devices, software packages, or a computer itself to work with network devices or with other hardware devices, software packages, or a computer over a network connection.
A feature introduced with Windows 2000 that allows administrators to enforce computer-specific and user-specific settings to domain-based computers.
A category for grouping or describing multimedia or games, such as music categorized as "classical" or "jazz".

A component of a scroll bar that allows the information to be scrolled by defined increments when the user clicks it. The direction of the arrow indicates the direction in which the information scrolls.

A component of a scroll bar that allows the information to be scrolled by defined increments when the user clicks it. The direction of the arrow indicates the direction in which the information scrolls.
A DVD from which the video section can be played on the DVD set top box. When inserted in the PC, the user can access additional features such as games, web links etc.
A photographic style and filter name that renders a photo in brown tones, mimicking the old-fashioned look of photos taken in the early part of the 20th century.
A pattern or mask through which data is passed to separate specified items.
The ~ character.
A hardware type for digital cameras and scanners.
To use for your benefit.
A standard Windows icon that represents a user’s private, usually local, storage.
The ¢ character.
A record of transactions or events that take place within an IT managed environment.
A toolbar that is not attached to the edge of the program window.
To cause text or an image to visually fade.
A proposed protocol standard that supports authentication and encryption to secure privacy in Internet communications. PCT is similar to the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) protocol.
A proposed protocol standard that supports authentication and encryption to secure privacy in Internet communications. PCT is similar to the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) protocol.
Pertaining to a process or content that is not associated with an identifiable user or originator.

A computer that acts as a source of information or signals. The host computer provides services, such as news, mail, or data, to computers that connect to it. The term can refer to almost any kind of computer, from a centralized mainframe that is a host to its terminals, to a server that is host to its clients, to a desktop PC that is host to its devices, such as printers and scanners.

A pointing device used mainly but not exclusively for computer games. A joystick has a base, on which control buttons can be mounted, and a vertical stem, which the user can move in any direction to control the movement of an object on the screen.
In reference to one or more computers, connected to a network.
A program that transforms a picture stored in one file format to another format so that it can be displayed in a specific graphics program.
The location (drive, folder, or directory) to which a file is copied or moved.
A location where email is delivered.

A written order on a bank to pay a sum of money from funds in an account. Checks show the name of the company or individual receiving payment, the signature and account number of the person issuing the check, the payment amount and the current date. Checks usually are numbered in sequence.
The process of aligning text along both the left and right margins.
A datasheet that is nested within another datasheet and that contains data related or joined to the first datasheet.
Protection of a computer system and its data from harm or loss.
The <> characters.

A physical hardware unit that can connect portable computers to a power source and to peripherals, such as a monitor, printer, full-sized keyboard, or mouse. The connection can be wireless or physical.
The capability of source code or programs developed on a more advanced system or compiler version to be executed or compiled by a less advanced (older) version.
A rule or procedure for solving a problem.
A file that contains some pre-defined formatting, layout, and/or text and graphics and that serves as the basis for new content with a similar look or purpose.
An arrangement of network devices that defines which devices are connected together.
An arrangement of network devices that defines which devices are connected together.
A message sent in real time through a network to a private chat area.
A bar at the top of the Excel window that you use to enter or edit values or formulas in cells or charts. Displays the constant value or formula stored in the active cell.
To copy files to a recordable CD.
A window that displays data from a table, form, query, view, or stored procedure in a row-and-column format.
A toolbar that contains buttons that allow users to perform some of the most common tasks in a Microsoft Office program, such as opening, saving, and printing files.
To move an item to a lower level within a tree structure.
A window that displays a form to either show or accept data. Form view is the primary means of adding and modifying data in tables. You cannot change the design of a form in this view.

A plastic (credit card–sized or smaller) device with an embedded microprocessor and a small amount of storage that is used, with an access code, to enable certificate-based authentication. Smart cards securely store certificates, public and private keys, passwords, and other types of personal information.

A plastic (credit card–sized or smaller) device with an embedded microprocessor and a small amount of storage that is used, with an access code, to enable certificate-based authentication. Smart cards securely store certificates, public and private keys, passwords, and other types of personal information.
A color that that is currently selected for drawing or displaying text on the screen.
On a Web page, a grouping of hyperlinks for getting around in that particular Web site.
The entity designated to receive something.
A number in the form a + bi, where a and b are real numbers and i = sqrt(-1) , so that bi is imaginary unless b = 0.
The window in which the main interaction with an object takes place.
A collection of information that is stored on a computer or device under a single name.
The process of verifying the identity of an entity, such as a user, computer, device, process, by validating the credentials provided by the entity.
A string of text that is displayed with one value for each text attribute: typeface, slant, and weight.
A process of converting readable data (plaintext) into a coded form (ciphertext) to prevent it from being read by an unauthorized party.
Software designed to provide access to a computer from a remote location. These programs are often installed by the computer owner or administrator, and are only a risk if unexpected.
A data-entry field on a page. A site visitor supplies information in a field either by typing text or by selecting a field.
A data type used to hold date and time information.
Pertaining to an entity, such as a user, a file or a computer that is currently connected a server.
The range and depth of a search on a portal site, desktop or other.
The range and depth of a search on a portal site, desktop or other.
The value of a scorecard element in relation to the values of other elements of the same type.
To follow the flow of information; to monitor progress.
The Office feature that automatically corrects errors and makes other substitutions as soon as a user types text.
An icon in Windows Vista Control Panel that opens a dialog allowing user to change display options including screen resolution, refresh rate, color depth, and orientation.

A keyboard key that, when pressed in combination with another key, gives that key an alternative meaning, for example, producing an uppercase character when a letter key is pressed. The SHIFT key is also used in various key combinations to create nonstandard characters or to perform special operations.

A folder or file name longer than the 8.3 file name standard (up to eight characters followed by a period and an extension of up to three characters). Most versions of Windows, including WindowsXP, Windows2000, WindowNT, Windows95, and Windows98 support long file names up to 255 characters.
A condition in which paper is blocked in the printing path of a printer, scanner, photocopier or fax machine.
A type of expansion board on PC-compatible computers that allows the playback and recording of sound, such as from a WAV or MIDI file or a music CD-ROM. Most PCs sold at retail include a sound card.
A type of expansion board on PC-compatible computers that allows the playback and recording of sound, such as from a WAV or MIDI file or a music CD-ROM. Most PCs sold at retail include a sound card.
A feature in Windows that makes it possible to use characters that are not displayed on the keyboard.
To move selected items to another location for long term storage.
A diagram that is used to show hierarchical relationships; for example, company management and employee structures.

An area in a PivotTable or PivotChart report where you can drop fields from the Field List dialog box to display the data in the field. The labels on each drop area indicate the types of fields you can create in the report.
Pertaining to a value that indicates missing or unknown data.
Comments and tracked changes such as insertions, deletions, and formatting changes.
A person who creates or maintains a weblog.
An area that shows available network connections and helps users quickly connect to the most appropriate one.

All elements included in the Query window, such as tables, criteria, the order in which fields are arranged, and so on. The design also specifies whether Auto Query is turned on, and whether you can edit the source data.
The default tab on the ribbon interface that provides the basic features that users need most frequently for each application.
The replay of a digital media file.
A single compressed file containing a collection of files and folders that duplicate a Windows installation on a disk volume.
A collection of elements that can be treated as a whole.
The option in Call Timers that allows the user to clear the accumulated time displayed by the Recent Calls timer.
A pane that lists all the fields in the underlying record source or database object.
A format consisting of ASCII codes in which database, spreadsheet, and similar documents can be structured to facilitate their use by and transfer to other programs.
A control on a form or report used to display and manipulate OLE objects that are stored in tables.
A global template that you can use for any type of document. You can modify this template to change the default document formatting or content.
A set of records that results from running a query or applying a filter.
A set of records that results from running a query or applying a filter.
A message that is sent over a communications network such as a local area network or the Internet.
A message that is sent over a communications network such as a local area network or the Internet.

An Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) standard that defines port-based network access control which either allows or denies connection requests to IEEE 802.3 wired Ethernet networks or IEEE 802.11 wireless networks.

An Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) standard that defines port-based network access control which either allows or denies connection requests to IEEE 802.3 wired Ethernet networks or IEEE 802.11 wireless networks.

An Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) standard that defines port-based network access control which either allows or denies connection requests to IEEE 802.3 wired Ethernet networks or IEEE 802.11 wireless networks.
Pertaining to a disk to which content cannot be recorded.
The × character.
A file backup feature that performs scheduled incremental backups of data to the target media. It also allows the user to restore an individual file or a group of files.
The uppermost directory on a computer, partition or volume.
The uppermost directory on a computer, partition or volume.
The protocol or protocols operating at a particular level within a protocol suite, such as IP within the TCP/IP suite.
A menu that shows only basic commands and commands that you use often.
A diagram that is used to show relationships of elements to a core element.
A UI element that creates a user session or establishes user access to a service.
To show something.

A database repository for information about a computer's configuration. The core of layered architecture that manages the most basic operations of the operating system and the computer's processor. The kernel schedules different blocks of executing code, called threads, for the processor to keep it as busy as possible and coordinates multiple processors to optimize performance. The kernel also synchronizes activities among Executive-level subcomponents, such as I/O Manager and Process Manager, and handles hardware exceptions and other hardware-dependent functions. The kernel works closely with the hardware abstraction layer.

A state in which your computer consumes less power when it is idle, but remains available for immediate use. While your computer is on standby, information in computer memory is not saved on your hard disk. If there is an interruption in power, the information in memory is lost.

A character used to align lines and columns on screen and in print. Although a tab is visually indistinguishable from a series of blank spaces in most programs, the tab character and the space character are different to a computer. A tab is a single character and therefore can be added, deleted, or overtyped with a single keystroke.

In a shared file, information that is maintained about changes made in past editing sessions. The information includes the name of the person who made each change, when the change was made, and what data was changed.
A portion of a software window bounded by and separated from other portions by vertical or horizontal bars and having a separate function.

An (API) that is provided as part of Microsoft Windows. An industry-standard Internet tunneling protocol that provides encapsulation for sending Point-to-Point Protocol (PPP) frames across packet-oriented media. For IP networks, L2TP traffic is sent as User Datagram Protocol (UDP) messages. In Microsoft operating systems, L2TP is used in conjunction with Internet Protocol security (IPSec) as a virtual private network (VPN) technology to provide remote access or router-to-router VPN connections. L2TP is described in RFC 2661.

A small pop-up window that describes the object being pointed to, such as a control, icon, or links. It contains more information than a standard tooltip.

A window that displays the SQL statement for the current query or that is used to create an SQL-specific query (union, pass-through, or data definition). When you create a query in Design view, Access constructs the SQL equivalent in SQL view.

A file that contains encoded information that is interpreted according to the application that created it. In general, a binary file can be edited only by the application in which it was created.
An interactive technology in Microsoft Excel or Access that can show dynamic views of the same data from a list or a database.

A graphic element that appears similar to a physical button or keyboard key in the UI. A button is "pressed" by clicking on it with a mouse, by hitting ENTER or RETURN on the keyboard (if the button has the focus) or tapping by a finger.

The key on the keyboard that is labeled with a left arrow.

A set of industry-standard framing and authentication protocols that are included with Windows to ensure interoperability with other remote access software. PPP negotiates configuration parameters for multiple layers of the Open Systems Interconnection (OSI) model. The Internet standard for serial communications, PPP defines how data packets are exchanged with other Internet-based systems using a modem connection. PPP is documented in RFC 1661.

An email security feature used to request confirmation that a message was received unaltered and information about who opened the message and when it was opened. This verification information is returned as a message to your Inbox.

An XML file with an .xsf extension that contains information about all other files and components used within a form, including user interface customizations, XML Schemas, views, business logic, events, and deployment settings.

The window in which a user is currently working or directing input. An active window is typically at the top of the Z order and is distinguished by the color of its title bar.
A unit of measure referring to the height of a printed character. A point equals 1/72 of an inch, or approximately 1/28 of a centimeter.

The part of the Microsoft Office user interface above the main work area that presents commands and options to the user. The Ribbon replaced menus and toolbars starting in the 2007 Microsoft Office system.
