A number assigned to a specific inventory item to identify it and differentiate it from similar items with the same item number.
To pick a command or an option from within a graphical user interface, as by clicking a button in a dialog box or pulling down a menu and then releasing the mouse button on one of its options.
A Web page editor command that inserts a horizontal line onto a Web page.
A tool that enables a user to sample the color of any pixel on a screen and apply that color to an object.
To assign or reserve a portion of an element, such as a resource or a session, for a particular use or purpose.

A page that contains the design and layout elements that you want to repeat on multiple pages in a publication. Using master pages for these common elements gives your publication a more consistent appearance.
A box with dotted borders in a slide layout that holds title and body text or objects such as charts, tables, and pictures.

A markup language for describing and exchanging structured data in a format that is independent of operating systems and applications. XML is a World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) specification and is a subset of Standard Generalized Markup Language (SGML).
The $ character.

A Windows security feature that locks a user account if a number of failed logon attempts occur within a specified amount of time, based on security policy lockout settings. Locked accounts cannot log on.
A line or row of characters used to lead the eye from a data label to a data point, or from a callout to the appropriate part of an illustration.
A field in a table that draws data from another table.
A feature that helps improve the recognition of a user's touch flicks by a process in which the user's touch flicks are analyzed.

An address that uniquely identifies a location on the Internet. A URL is usually preceded by http://, as in http://www.microsoft.com. A URL can contain more detail, such as the name of a page of hypertext, often with the file name extension .html or .htm.

In statistical or scientific data, a bar that shows the potential error or degree of uncertainty relative to each data marker in a series.
The points where playback of a file or clip begins and ends. There are two trim points: start trim point and end trim point.

The , character.
The title of instructions for setting up and preparing the device for first use.
A query that retrieves data stored on your intranet or the Internet.
A predefined or free-form figure — such as a line, oval, cube, flowchart symbol, banner, or free-form scribble — that the user can insert into a document and then customize.
In computer graphics, a display method in which a viewing window on the screen scans horizontally or vertically, like a camera, to bring offscreen extensions of the current image smoothly into view.

A common point of entry for spyware guarded by an agent. Examples of checkpoints include Startup Folder, dial up connections, Wi-Fi connections, Internet Safe Sites, Winsock Layered Service Providers, Windows Messenger Service, and SPAM Zombie prevention.
A numeric or string value that is not calculated and, therefore, does not change.
To enlarge a window to its largest size by double-clicking the title bar, clicking the Maximize button (at the right of the title bar), or by pressing ALT+SPACEBAR and then pressing X.
Pertaining to an operator that can hold an arbitrary number of arguments, or to a function that can hold an arbitrary number of operators.
Capable of being retrieved (read), printed or copied but not changed (written) or saved.
On a local area network (LAN), a drive that other computers on the network can connect to. A network drive allows people to access shared files and folders.
An on-screen box, in a graphical user interface, that is used to deliver a message or warning.

A hidden section of an email message. From the time a message is first created, information about it is added to the message header, including technical details, such as who created the message and the software used to compose it.
The title for a dialog that specifies how a signature line should be signed, including instructions for signers.
Having a frequency in the electromagnetic spectrum in the range just below that of red light.
A measure of processing power, given in megahertz (MHz).
A field defined in a query that displays the result of an expression rather than displaying stored data. The value is recalculated each time a value in the expression changes.
To create an object, such as an email message.
The ≤ character.

Characterized by conversational exchange of input and output, as when a user enters a question or command and the system immediately responds. The interactivity of microcomputers is one of the features that makes them approachable and easy to use.

A data structure that is a collection of fields (elements), each with its own name and type. Unlike an array, whose elements all represent the same type of information and are accessed using an index, the elements of a record represent different types of information and are accessed by name. A record can be accessed as a collective unit of elements, or the elements can be accessed individually.

To place information from storage into memory for processing, if it is data, or for execution, if it is program code.
The "digital persona" by which other users recognize and interact with you.

A window that shows the design of these database objects - tables, queries, forms, reports, macros, and data access pages. In Design view, you can create new database objects and modify the design of existing ones.

Pertaining to time on a schedule when a person may participate in a scheduled task.

A uniquely-named collection of computers in a networked environment that share a common database, directory database, or tree and that is administered as a unit with common rules and procedures, which can include security policies.

A formal or legally binding agreement between two or more parties.
Formatting that controls the appearance of a text. Examples include text alignment, intercharacter spacing, text justification, and text and background colors.

A feature that allows the user to select from a gallery of pre-defined formatting styles and apply them quickly to tables, text, charts, drawing objects and SmartArt graphics.

A secure email feature that lets you add sensitivity labels, such as Internal Use Only, to the message header. Security labels in your organization are controlled by security policies set up by your email administrator.

The cell in which each input value from a data table is substituted. Any cell on a worksheet can be the input cell. Although the input cell does not need to be part of the data table, the formulas in data tables must refer to the input cell.
The adjustment of the spacing between two characters to create the appearance of even spacing, fit text to a given space, and adjust line breaks.
One character (or more) printed slightly below the baseline of surrounding text.
In the context of processes or tasks that are part of an operating system or program, operating without interaction with the user while the user is working on another task.
To advance audio or video playback at a speed that is faster than normal.

A type of attack that tries to trick users into revealing personal information, such as credit card numbers, bank accounts, or passwords, often using links to fake websites included in emails and chat messages.

The faint vertical and horizontal lines that appear in the drawing window when the grid is turned on. You can use grid lines to help position shapes precisely.

The point that defines the layout of grid lines on the drawing page. A vertical grid line and a horizontal grid line pass through the grid origin, and all other grid lines are drawn at specified intervals from these reference lines.
A line that connects fields between two tables and shows how the data is related. The type of join indicates which records are selected for the query's result set.

The special characters used to extend the joiner between two Arabic characters. Used to improve the appearance of justified text by visually lengthening words rather than increasing the spacing between words. Can also function like a hyphen.
Resolving resource conflicts or overallocations by delaying or splitting certain tasks. When Project levels a resource, its selected assignments are distributed and rescheduled.
A type of cascading style sheet that exists in a separate file and is referenced throughout one or more Web pages.
A shape on a stencil that you use repeatedly to create drawings. When you drag a shape from a stencil onto the drawing page, the shape becomes an instance of that master.
The result of assigning more tasks to a resource than the resource can accomplish in the working time available.
A view of a list, SharePoint document library, or Web Part Page that is available only to a particular user.
A schedule of task start and finish dates and resource and cost data.
Placing elements, such as text and graphics, on a page to let the page author control the exact location and layer order of a page element.
The degree of excellence, or the desired standards, in a product, process, or project.
A category of reports that all contain similar information.
A representation of the communication path between actors.
An actor's interface component through which actors communicate with other actors.
Any one-dimensional (1-D) shape that can be glued between two shapes in a drawing to connect the shapes.
To change the dimensions of a shape by dragging one of its handles after it has been selected with the pointer tool.
A small overlap that extends the shape of the upper of two differently colored, abutting objects. A spread extends beyond the area that it knocks out.
The default text font for worksheets. The standard font determines the default font for the Normal cell style.
A date that you set [rather than the current date] for reporting the time, cost, or performance condition of a project.
A description of the status of a member's project work and related work.

A task that is made up of subtasks and summarizes those subtasks. Use outlining to create summary tasks. Project automatically determines summary task information [such as duration and cost] by using information from the subtasks.
An horizontal or vertical line that divides a diagram into partitions and which is used to arrange related parts of a process.

The time period indicator at the top of the Gantt views, the Resource Graph view, the Task Usage view, and the Resource Usage view. You can customize it to show up to three tiers that can display various time units: top, middle, and bottom.

A folder or file path on your computer or a location on your intranet from which it is safe to run code. Default trusted locations include the Templates, Addins, and Startup folders, and you can specify your own trusted locations.
The percentage of a work resource’s time that is assigned to a task.
A bar displayed along the left side of a document window. You can use the vertical ruler to adjust the top and bottom page margins and the row height in tables.
A calendar in widespread use. It was introduced in 1582 A.D. as a revision to the Julian calendar.
An XML structure that consists of a start tag, an end tag, and the information between the tags. Elements can have attributes and can contain other elements.
Pertaining to information that shows what has actually occurred. For example, the actual start date for a task is the day that the task actually started.
The percentage of a resource's capacity that is designated for a specific assignment.
Having a digital signature.
The number of levels that a task is indented from the top level of the outline. You can indent tasks up to 65,000 levels in Project.
A group of related tasks that completes a major step in a project.
Conditions you specify to limit which records are included in the result set of a query or filter.
A diagram that shows dependencies between project tasks. Tasks are represented by boxes, or nodes, and task dependencies are represented by lines that connect the boxes.
Text that you enter by using a keyboard or that your Tablet PC converts from handwriting or speech.
A view that displays resource information. Resource views include the Resource Sheet, the Resource Graph, the Resource Usage, and the resource forms views.
A notification that is displayed to a user when user-defined criteria are met.
Software that enables parents and guardians to customize children's web experiences in order to help protect their safety and privacy online.
The folder that by default receives new messages.
A tool that enables a user to get another user's attention by shaking the user's conversation window and playing a sound.
An animated greeting a customer can send to a contact.
To package your publication files by using the Pack and Go Wizard.
An effect that applies a halo of color around the perimeter of an object.
To display an object.
The size of the finished page of a printed publication, after trimming.
The size of the sheet of paper on which you print the publication, before trimming.
A word or string of characters in a formula that represents a cell, range of cells, formula, or constant value.
A name for an Excel table, which is a collection of data about a particular subject that is stored in records (rows) and fields (columns).
A control on most digital cameras that lets you control the under -or over- exposure of the image.
An effect that applies to the appearance of the interior of an enclosed text character or other shape.
A file that contains the data that a program will process and store in a destination file.
A collection of communications (email, IM, text messaging, voice mail, and so on) between two or more participants.
A short alphanumeric message that is sent between mobile phones or devices using the SMS protocol.

Extra information displayed to a user while they are composing an email message. MailTips are displayed in an InfoBar, similar to the banner that appears saying "This message has not been sent." MailTips reveal anything that might be unexpected about the delivery or audience of the message, such as recipient validity or Out of Office status or whether the message might not be delivered.

A collection of shapes arranged in a tree structure that helps analyze and summarize data in a visual, easy-to-understand format. It starts out as a single shape, called a top node, that contains information imported from a worksheet, table, view, or cube.
The status of an item in source control that reflects one or more changes from a previous form. The greater the version number, the more recent the version.
A set of data items that contains a unique identifier, called a key, and a value that is the actual data for the key.
The sound made by a mobile device or other phone to indicate an incoming call or message, for example, a series of beeps or an audio recording.

An authentication device that digitally scans an individual's fingerprint, records the unique pattern of the individual's ridges and valleys, and determines if the pattern matches the pattern of the person who has access permission to a particular device, such as a computer or a phone, or to a Web site.
A renamed .cab file which contains a .theme file, and optionally one or more desktop backgrounds, icons, mouse pointer files, and sound files. It does not contain executables or screen savers.
A renamed .ini file that points to the theme resources and contains theme values such as colors, fonts, and window size metrics.
A button that replaces the File menu beginning with some 2007 Microsoft Office system programs.
To monitor an email conversation or newsgroup thread. The headers for messages in a watched conversation appear in a different color, which makes them easier to find in a message list.

An option on the Views menu in File Explorer that shows the most appropriate details for the file type in a flexible layout rather than only showing the details associated with the column headers in the view.

A gallery that allows users to create a quick rule to move mail to a selected folder based on the sender, recipients, or conversation of the currently selected email message without opening the full Create Rule dialog.
A group of computers on a home network that can share pictures, music, videos, documents, and printers. A homegroup is created by using the HomeGroup feature; it is protected with a password.
A password that helps prevent unauthorized access to homegroup files and printers.
A digital or paper format pack that usually consists of a proof of purchase, the description of the licensing terms and policies, and number of client access licenses (CALs) purchased in this pack.
An action that removes redundant messages from an email conversation to reduce information overload and improve readability.
A fork within a conversation, where more than one reply was made to a single email and caused a split in the conversation.
A collection of items, such as files and folders, assembled from various locations. The locations might be on your computer, an external hard drive, removable media, or someone else’s computer.
To mark an item so that it always appears in a specific place in the UI or in a list.
To remove an item, such as a tile, library, movie, game, or app, from a given area of the UI, to make it inaccessible in that area.
A user with role-based permission who can change settings for apps, services, users, subscriptions, and/or devices.
A Microsoft account that manages a subscription.
To come upon through action.
A pencil tool that works with texture and simulates a real life pencil in stroke.
A Windows feature that enables users to easily roll back their PC to an earlier good state while keeping their data safe.
A process by which multiple authors edit a shared document simultaneously, or collaborate effectively even when they are not online at the same time.

A client-side cache for documents that are stored on Web servers. Documents are seamlessly replicated from this local cache, and uploaded to servers as required, enabling faster and more robust file access.
A feature that provides access to gallery of frequently-used actions with the touch of a button. Users can customize the gallery to execute a combination of operations in one click.
A frame that contains text, shapes, pictures, or other content. A slide is a digital equivalent to a traditional film slide.
To mark an email conversation so that all current and future messages in the conversation are automatically moved to the Deleted Items folder.
A special control that shows pictures, names and titles of people who are attending a meeting, or who are the recipients of an email message.
A feature that allows the user to apply custom or default markers to items (e.g. Outlook messages or OneNote content) in order to categorize information for easy retrieval and sorting.
A feature that allows the user to apply custom or default markers to items (e.g. Outlook messages or OneNote content) in order to categorize information for easy retrieval and sorting.

Any hardware or software that can detect events or environmental changes, such as your current location or the amount of light around your computer. For example, a notebook with a location sensor, such as a Global Positioning System (GPS) receiver, can determine your exact location. An ambient light sensor can detect when there is a change in lighting, and then a program can use that information to adjust the brightness of your screen.

A device that includes an antenna, a radio receiver, and a processor for use with the worldwide GPS (Global Positioning System). A GPS receiver uses position and time information from four GPS satellites to calculate precise information about its current location, its speed of travel, and the current time.
A category of sensor that can detect the current location of your computer.

Technologies that measure and analyze physical and behavioral human characteristics, such as fingerprints, eye retinas and irises, voice patterns, facial patterns, hand measurements, typing patterns and signatures, to recognize or authenticate identity.
An area within the Windows Control Panel that provides support for sensors such as enabling, disabling or uninstalling sensors and sensor-enabled applications, changing sensor settings, etc.
A light sensor that tracks light in the surroundings and therefore the amount of backlight needed for the LCD screen to be adjusted accordingly.

A package of market-specific content delivered in Windows for 20 target markets. A Local Pack contains market-customized themes (wallpapers, sound schemes, etc.) and locally flavored Internet Explorer favorites and RSS feeds.
An area within the Windows Control Panel that allows the user to designate his home coordinates or address for location-aware functionalities.
An arrangement of search results ordered by relevance using a special search algorithm.

A framework that provides a single point for IT professionals and OEMs to service and maintain Windows images offline through a scriptable command line utility and an easily extensible infrastructure.
A gadget that users can display on their desktop, rather than on the Windows Sidebar. Examples are clocks, news headlines, slide shows, and weather forecasts.
Automatic display adjustment that changes the brightness of your PC screen (laptop and desktop) using light environment information provided by the ambient light sensor.
A single set of sign-in credentials (typically, email address and password) that is used to access the services provided by an online service provider (OSP).
A single set of sign-in credentials (typically, email address and password) that is used to access the services provided by an online service provider (OSP).
A provider of online services like email, messaging, and others (example: Windows Live, Yahoo, Google).
The process of maintaining connectivity outside of one's usual service or coverage area.
A collaborative action, such as sharing, calendar sharing, or using a whiteboard.
An email that a customer does not want delivered to their inbox, including spam and phishing messages (identified by the mail service) and messages from blocked senders and domains.

A set of colors and background images that lets users change the appearance of Windows Live pages. The theme is common to all pages, except for group, event, and space pages, which may each have their own theme.
To copy something from a computer to a location online, such as a photo album or a blog post.
Parental consent for a child to use a service, view a website, or communicate with a person.
A SmartArt graphic layout type that includes layouts designed to show nonsequential information.
A SmartArt graphic layout type that includes layouts designed to show steps in a process or timeline.
A SmartArt graphic layout type that includes layouts designed to show a continual process.
A SmartArt graphic layout type that includes layouts designed to show how parts relate to a whole.

The descriptive information about a user that is shown to other users. This editable information is separate from the registration information they provide to establish their Windows Live account. This separation allows users to disclose or conceal personal information as they choose.

A horizontal grouping of actions that apply to the container (or containers) with which the toolbar is associated. For example, a container in which mail is viewed might have an action toolbar with options that include Reply, Delete, and Move to.
A disk image provided for use in repairing or reinstalling an installation of Windows.
A recognition feature that helps increase input speed and reduce effort by providing users with word completion and next word prediction alternates as the user is writing/typing.
An extension of the conventional touch input feature to allow multiple fingers touching the computer or device screen at the same time.
A multi-touch gesture that consists of one or two fingers moving in the same direction, parallel to each other.
A multi-touch gesture that consists of one or two fingers moving in the same direction, parallel to each other.
A multi-touch gesture that consists of two fingers moving in opposite directions (-> <- or <- ->).
A multi-touch gesture that consists of two fingers moving around a center point or one finger moving around a finger that is not moving.
The engine that specifically recognizes and processes touch input and multi-touch input as commands.
A collection of computing resources such as programs and virtual desktops that enable a user to accomplish a set of related tasks.

The entity that offers a remote workspace, typically the IT department of the user’s employer, a business partner or vendor, or less commonly, a commercial application service provider. The publisher may use a digital certificate to represent its identity and use it to sign the remote resource files (e.g. RDP files) and the workspace description (e.g. Web Service feed).
Silent and unexpected process termination by the process itself or by another application.
To shut down a core processor for power saving purpose.
To reopen a core processor that had been parked for power saving purpose.
A feature of Windows Media Player that allows users to remove gaps between tracks that they burn to audio CDs.
Existing in reference to the removal of silences or clicks between tracks when they are burnt to an audio CD or when they are played back from the CD.
A unique identifier made from four otherwise separate pieces of information. For example, a color can be specified by a black, yellow, magenta and cyan quad.
Any information (e.g. account numbers, sensitive data, etc.) with a title and some free-form text that can be stored in a secure manner in a personal vault.
To make an object, such as a file, accessible.
A feature that replicates the animation associated with a source object to one or more target objects.
An abstract grouping of similar animation effects.
An effect that a user can apply to an image to achieve a specific artistic look.
A visual representation of an audio signal over time.
An image editing feature that allows a user to isolate the foreground portion of an image and make the background transparent.
An option that removes narrations and laser pointer gestures or timings from a presentation or from a specific slide.
The ability of software to support customer-preferred algorithms for encryption, hashing, entropy and digital signatures.
The ability of software to support customer-preferred algorithms for encryption, hashing, entropy and digital signatures.
To remove a user's changes from the Microsoft Office Document Cache without deleting the file on the server or removing the latest version downloaded from the server from the Office Document Cache.
A security feature that validates files before allowing them to be loaded by the application, in order to protect against file format vulnerabilities.
A feature that allows end users and IT admins to control which file types and versions can be opened and saved in the application.

A feature that allows the user to superimpose a dot over a presentation and control its position with the mouse. The appearance of the dot is similar to that of a traditional laser pointer, and it is broadcast to all presentation viewers and can be recorded into video (Save to Video).
An option that initiates an email response addressed to all of the recipients on the To or Cc lines of the original message.
An option that initiates an email response addressed to all of the recipients on the To or Cc lines of the original message.
The mode of Windows Photo Viewer which consists of a top level window displaying one photograph at a time, with navigation controls.
A mode of Windows Photo Viewer which displays full-screen slide shows for photos.
A recordable media (such as CD-RW) to which you can only write once without reformatting.
A recordable media to which you can write several times without reformatting.
A feature that is added to the Microsoft Office Compatibility Pack to open Word, Excel, and PowerPoint binary format files and securely convert them to the Office 2007 file formats.
A feature that makes Outlook auto-complete lists available through the default Exchange mailbox.

A common credential store and interface that is used to save and manage user credentials, such as user names and passwords, so you can easily log on to Web sites and connect to other resources, such as computers.
A set of credentials that users can create, store and manage in Credential Manager.
A type of vault that contains Web passwords and secure notes that you can place on a USB flash drive and use on another computer.
A control in a form that consists of an actionable image. At run time the user can click the image to run rules or actions similar to a button.

A feature that enables presenters in the rich client to broadcast a slide show to remote viewers watching in a Web browser. Throughout the presentation, the remote attendees will see the current slide being shown by the presenter.
A labeled group of consecutive slides that helps the user navigate and organize presentations.
A labeled group of consecutive slides that helps the user navigate and organize presentations.
A feature that allows the user to insert the contents of an open window or a screen clipping into the current document without the need to utilize external applications.
A feature that makes automatic versions of user documents during each autosave operation and allows the user to revert to previous copies of the document with ease.
A feature that alerts users to potential issues with email recipients before the message is sent.
To establish a Bluetooth link or connection between two Bluetooth–enabled devices.
A feature that displays a definition or translation of a word or piece of text in a ScreenTip when the pointer is moved over the selection.

To copy driver binaries, install services, and add registry keys for one or more drivers from a driver package onto a system, without the context of a specific device. A system can be booted from reflected drivers, however full device installation may still be required in order to enable full driver functionality.
A Windows feature that enables users to share pictures, music, videos, documents, and printers with other people on a home network.
An abstract grouping of similar transition effects.

A full-page UI view that exposes file-level functionality in Office applications. This is a companion feature to the Office Ribbon and helps users discover and use the features that fall outside of the authoring features on the Ribbon.

A full-page UI view that exposes file-level functionality in Office applications. This is a companion feature to the Office Ribbon and helps users discover and use the features that fall outside of the authoring features on the Ribbon.
A digital distribution provider of games such as MSN Games, Yahoo Games, Steam, Stardock, GameTap, and so on.
A file used as part of a testing process to check the validity or correctness of a program or procedure.
A feature that helps users of some Office applications to improve the accessibility of documents they create.
An instant message that is transmitted while the sender or recipient is offline.
The helper program that can store sign-in information for multiple Windows Live IDs.

termGrp.term: Помоћник за пријаву у Windows Live

descripGrp.descrip: A feature that offers improved security by loading a document in a read-only view, rather than in the full editor, for scenarios that pose a greater potential security risk.
A package containing everything you need to show one or many PowerPoint presentations on another computer. This package can be saved to a folder or burned to a CD.

A feature that allows the user to indicate that a document is trusted, and therefore can be opened without security notifications, so long as the file path and creation time of the document remain unchanged.
The contact picture label that indicates someone has been invited to do something, but has not responded yet.
The link to the webpage where a user manages photos and albums.
The link to the main landing/start page on Windows Live.
The process of establishing a Bluetooth link or connection between two Bluetooth–enabled devices.
A Windows library that allows users to store, manage and share all their recorded TV items.
A Windows service that provides software licensing activation and notification.
A set of attributes that define a user's access to a given service or application.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to compare or show the relationship between two ideas. Each of the first two lines of Level 1 text corresponds to text at the top of one side of the center point. Emphasizes Level 2 text, which is limited to four shapes on each side of the center point. The balance tips towards the side with the most shapes containing Level 2 text. Unused text does not appear, but remains available if you switch layouts.
A SmartArt graphic layout used to show sequential steps or tasks that depict a plan or result. The last Level 1 line of text appears after the equals sign (=).Works best with Level 1 text only.

A SmartArt graphic layout used to show grouped or related information of equal value. The first Level 1 line of text corresponds to the top shape and its Level 2 text is used for the subsequent lists.
A company that provides services or content for its customers.

A piece of hardware that supports multiple discrete capabilities, such as audio, mixer, and music, on a single card. This device is sometimes treated as a bus that can be enumerated to locate the devices on that bus.
To expose a virtual disk to the user, backed by a file.

The administrative task of making remote resources available to its users, setting policies that control how users will connect, how they will find the remote resources, and what settings users will connect with.
A feature that provides an interface for acquiring rich metadata in order to support showing device detail information in the Device Center and the Device Stage.
A .cab file that can only have one locale support and that provides all the hardware display components in order for your device information to be shown in the Control Panel.
A .cab file that can only have one locale support and that provides all the hardware display components in order for your device information to be shown in the Control Panel.
To uninstall all software on a computer and reinstall a new Windows image.
An easy-to-use troubleshooter that helps find and fix program compatibility issues.
A small pop-up window that informs users of a non-critical problem or special condition in a control.
A category of sensor that collects biometric data for a variety of applications.
A sensor that uses ultrasound, infrared, heat or vibration stimuli to detect movement.
A biometric sensor that analyses your eye retina to recognize or authenticate identity.
A category of sensor that can respond to an applied stimulus by generating an electrical signal.
A category of sensor that is used for mechanical measurement of force, scale, pressure, strain, etc.
A category of sensor that tracks environmental changes such as temperature, atmospheric pressure, humidity, wind speed and wind direction.
A type of sensor that can determine without physical contact if an object/person is nearby, or can be used to measure the distance between the object/person and the sensor device.

termGrp.term: сензор за идентифицирање присуства ствари и људи

descripGrp.descrip: A type of sensor (such as a proximity sensor) that uses radio frequency identification (RFID) for a numerous purposes, such as identification of physical items, automatic log on, location of people, etc.

A type of sensor (such as a proximity sensor) that uses radio frequency identification (RFID) for a numerous purposes, such as identification of physical items, automatic log on, location of people, etc.
A sensor that responds to a pre-defined amount of light.
To remove a Bluetooth link or connection between two Bluetooth–enabled devices.

A command prompt that is run in a privileged administrator security context that allows actions that would normally be restricted. Without elevation, command prompts in Windows Client and Windows Server run in a restricted state.
The link group that includes links to the About Hotmail webpage, the What's New webpage, and so on.
The Windows Live service for event planning and invitations.

The link that appears above an incomplete content set and leads to the full list of items. For example, when a content module displays items 1–6, a "View all" link in line with the module label leads to a webpage that lists all items. The items that are available in preview are redundantly available in the list of all items, which may be paginated.
A piece of feedback left by someone viewing content on a site.
A computer that belongs to a homegroup.
A troubleshooter that helps find and fix problems with viewing computers or shared files in a homegroup.

termGrp.term: алат за поправке рачунара кућне групе

descripGrp.descrip: To group together multiple windows of the same application under a single button on the taskbar’s taskband.

termGrp.term: поставити једну типку за више прозора

descripGrp.descrip: A feature that allows the user to digitally alter a picture to increase or decrease the sharpness of focus.
An organizer used to add, uninstall, and search for desktop gadgets.
A program that helps make the text on your screen easier to read for long periods of time.
A virtual device created by System Restore that is needed to set a system restore point.

termGrp.term: уређај за брзи снимак носитеља података

descripGrp.descrip: A software or device that helps control your home smart devices automatically.

An input device used chiefly for identification purposes that reads information that has been magnetically encoded, usually in two tracks, on a plastic card, such as a credit card or an employee badge.
A notebook that is smaller in size and lighter in weight than a full-sized notebook, while retaining the same functionality.
A gallery containing thumbnail views of open application windows.
A primary storage device based on solid-state memory, such as flash memory, that provides nonvolatile storage with benefits of performance, reliability and power saving.
A node that makes cached data available to clients needing to retrieve the data.
To apply a marker to content or items (like photos or text) to identify certain types of information.
A method of blocking access to websites based on their content. For example, In Windows Live Family Safety, parents can specify a filtering level, such as Strict or Basic, for their child.
An audio or video file that you rent from an online store, typically for a monthly fee.
A troubleshooter that performs common maintenance tasks in Windows, such as cleaning up unused files and shortcuts.
A troubleshooter that helps find and fix problems about hardware and devices.

termGrp.term: алат за проблеме хардвера и уређаја

descripGrp.descrip: A search location exposed via .osdx templates and made possible via the OpenSearch technology. It connects the local search indexer to a remote index and provides the end user with the ability to search for files on a Web site or on an intranet site from within Windows.
A feature that provides one-click filtering controls that make it easy to narrow down the portion of a data set that's being looked at.
A miniature chart that can be inserted into text or embedded within a cell on a worksheet to illustrate highs, lows, and trends in your data.
An Outlook Calendar view in which each calendar is listed vertically (not side-by-side). This view is optimized for viewing a schedule for a group and scheduling a meeting for a group.
A feature that converts each slide in a presentation into a single image and rebuilds a new, compressed PPT presentation that can easily be shared, but not edited.

A Windows Media Player (WMP) specific feature that allows you to use the Internet to access music, pictures and videos available on your home network. The feature must be activated on at least two computers in order to work.

An icon that is attached to an event and that is viewable in someone's calendar. Depending on the calendar view, a charm may appear next to an event title, or may be the only visual representation of an event on a calendar day.
A view that shows all of the resources on a project and their work over time. This makes it easy to rearrange work, schedule new work, and manage a team's load.
A feature that allows the application of tags to individual Outlook items to specify retention policy for that message, conversation or other item.
To permit someone else to perform an action.
The navigation button used to return to recently visited Web pages in Internet Explorer, Microsoft Edge, and other internet browsers.

Information that describes the current location of a computer. The location is entered manually in Default Location, and can be used by programs to determine the location of a computer when a location sensor is unavailable.
A term that can be added to a search to filter the results by a specific property (for example, by author). Relevant search filters appear under the search box in any open folder.
A type of corruption that affects the data in the Windows heap, such as damages caused by a buffer overrun, writing to a stray pointer or a double-free.

A soft keyboard that is displayed with a different set of settings by default (larger buttons, bigger size, etc.) when you launch the Tablet PC Input Panel with touch. This is to facilitate touch input.

A two-way device provided by a cable provider that enables some one-way digital CableCARD-based consumer electronic devices such as high-definition DVRs and Media Center PCs to access digital cable channels delivered using switched digital video.
A real-time, physical action applied to an object, in which multiple contact points are used simultaneously.

A device used to write CD-ROMs. Because a disc can be written only once on these machines, they are used most commonly to create CD-ROMs for data archives or to produce CD-ROM masters that can be duplicated for mass distribution.
A feature that ensures that all components of a file are preserved, even if they are supported only by the rich client and not viewable in Web Companions.
The heading for information about the time at which something was added, changed, or re-posted.
A customizable page that launches with Windows Live Messenger and features a summary of news and weather, allows a customer to preview their Windows Live Mail inbox and search the Internet.
The title of the window in which the Windows Live Messenger Today page is displayed.

A set of features that enables users to improve the quality of their images with just one or two clicks. Galleries help the user optimize characteristics such as brightness, contrast, color, and sharpness.
A feature that enables Tablet PC users to convert an ink drawing to a standard OfficeArt shape, which can be formatted with colors and effects exactly as if it were inserted using “Insert Shape.”

A feature that enables presenters to capture all the elements of a live presentation, including narration, slides, mouse clicks, A/V playback, and laser pointer highlights. The user can select which presentation aspects to record.

A slide show mode that displays content in a manageable window that can be resized and features navigation buttons. This mode is optimized for reviewing presentations, allowing users to get the full experience, complete with animations and media, while performing other tasks, such as taking notes.

A feature that allows users to easily add links to content within other content (e.g. pages, sections, section groups) and provides quick navigation through these links. The feature operates in the same manner that links work in wikis.
A feature that highlights new or changed content in a shared notebook that the user has not yet read.
A high-level linear representation of a project schedule that can be easily formatted, annotated, and copied and pasted from Project into other Office applications.
A feature that identifies the author of unread new or changed content in a shared notebook.
A task pane that helps form designers to build and manage custom business rules for use in their forms.
A pre-defined table style that allows users to change the look and feel of a form.
A feature that allows form designers to select from a gallery of pre-built rules to make their forms dynamic.
A pre-defined layout that users can select for their InfoPath form sections. Options include single column, two-column, three-column, and four-column layouts.
An environment in the InfoPath client that enables users to fill out forms (as opposed to designing them). It must be used if the forms to be filled out are not browser-compatible.
The street address or geographical coordinates of a user, and (by way of extensions) of the user’s computer or devices.
To save the user's work on a continuous basis, so that it is not necessary to save manually.

A user role in the engagement functionality in Microsoft Social Listening. A person with the Responder role can add, edit, and share social accounts they own, edit post metadata (sentiment, assignments), and publish posts via their social accounts.
A user role in the Engagement functionality of Social Listening. A person with the Reader role can read posts from streams that are made available to them.
A data structure that contains authentication and authorization information for a user.
A profile on a social network that is owned and maintained by one or more individuals within Microsoft Social Engagement.
A chronological list of posts to monitor that match user-defined criteria.
Real-time visualization of a steady stream of posts on a map. Fresh posts show up as they come in and older posts fade out of the map after a user-defined amount of time.

The highly scalable event-processing engine that helps uncover real-time insights from devices, sensors, infrastructure, applications and data.
